text: The first principle is that you must not fool yourself— and you are the easiest person to fool.
author: Richard P. Feynman (1918–1988)

text: The computer is incredibly fast, accurate, and stupid.Man is unbelievably slow, inaccurate, and brilliant.Together they are powerful beyond imagination.
author: Leo Cherne (1912–1999)

text: Everything should be made as simple as possible, but not simpler.
author: Albert Einstein (1879–1955)

text: All models are wrong, but some are useful.
author: George E. P. Box (1919–2013)

text: The map is not the territory.
author: Alfred Korzybski (1879–1950)

text: In God we trust; all others must bring data.
author: W. Edwards Deming (1900–1993) — attributed

text: The purpose of computing is insight, not numbers.
author: Richard Hamming (1915–1998)

text: How you do one thing is how you do everything.
author: Unknown — commonly attributed to Martha Beck (b. 1962) and T. Harv Eker (b. 1954)

text: If you see fraud and do not say fraud, you are a fraud.
author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb (b. 1960)

text: The only way out is through.
author: Robert Frost
